review.title: Using Distributed Representations to Disambiguate Biomedical and Clinical Concepts
review.abstract: In this paper, we report a knowledge-based method for Word Sense Disambiguation in the domains of biomedical and clinical text. We combine word representations created on large corpora with a small number of definitions from the UMLS to create concept representations, which we then compare to representations of the context of ambiguous terms. Using no relational information, we obtain comparable performance to previous approaches on the MSH-WSD dataset, which is a well-known dataset in the biomedical domain. Additionally, our method is fast and easy to set up and extend to other domains. Supplementary materials, including source code, can be found at https: //github.com/clips/yarn

metadata.title: Using Distributed Representations to Disambiguate Biomedical and Clinical Concepts

sections.text: In this article, we report on a knowledge-based method of word sense disambiguation in biomedical and clinical text. We combine word representations created on large corpora with a small number of definitions from UMLS to create conceptual representations, which we then compare with representations of the context of ambiguous terms. As we do not use relational information, we get a similar performance to previous approaches to the MSH WSD dataset, a known dataset in the biomedical field. In addition, our method is quick and easy to set up and expand to other areas. Complementary materials, including source code, can be found at https: / / github.com / clips / yarn

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Word Sense Disambiguation (WSD) is a process in which an ambiguous term or concept is assigned a single meaning suitable for that context, and is an important step in creating a semantic representation of a document (Ide and Ve ́ ronis, 1998). While the implementation of WSD will favor most natural language processing applications, the disambigualization of concepts is a critical component of applications based on clinical and biomedical texts in which the same word can denote different concepts, and can therefore elicit radically different reactions. This problem of ambiguity is the fact that clinical text is generally louder than other areas and contains a wide variety of abbreviations, some of which may be specific to a single hospital or physician. Furthermore, there is a distinct absence of large amounts of commented clinical texts, even in English, which poses a problem for supervised approaches to Word Sense Disambiguation.

sections.heading: 3.1 Test Corpus
sections.text: We use the MSH-WSD corpus (Jimeno-Yepes et al., 2011), which consists of a series of 203 ambiguous terms, each associated with several concepts, to evaluate our approach. Of the 203 terms in the corpus, 106 are regular terms, 88 acronyms, and 9 can be acronyms and regular terms. Up to 100 MeSH abstracts have been retrieved for each of these concepts, resulting in a set of 37,888 abstracts. In our approach, all abstracts have been pre-processed using the tokenizer from the Pattern package (De Smedt and Daelemans, 2012), and all stopwords have been removed from Scikit learning using the English stopword list (Pedregosa et al., 2011).

sections.heading: 3.2 Word vectors
sections.text: We evaluate our approach using three sets of vectors: the first set was trained using a small set of Medline abstracts1, and a second set of vectors created on the entirety of the MIMIC III corpus of clinical notes (Johnson et al., 2016). For both sets, we used the word2vec implementation of gensim (R-ehu-r-ek and Sojka, 2010), using negative sampling skip programs, a frequency intersection1 The specific IDs of these abstracts are in the online appendix of 5 and a negative sample of 15. In addition, we used a third set of vectors available at the BioASQ organizers2, which was trained on a much larger set of Medline abstracts2. 3 The model statistics are visualized in Table 1.

sections.heading: 4 Approach
sections.text: Similar to the 2-MRD approach described above, our approach creates concept vectors by replacing each word in each definition with the vector representation of that word. This generates an M × n matrix for each definition, where M is the dimensionality of the word vector, and n the number of words contained in that definition. Then, for each definition, we obtain a single vector of dimensionality M, applying a compositional function to the matrix, giving us so-called definition vectors that represent the entire meaning of the definition in a vector. Each concept can then be represented by an M × d matrix, where d is the number of definitions that a concept has in the UMLS. Finally, we apply a second compositional function to this matrix, giving us a single vector of dimensionality M that represents the combined meaning of all definitions.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion and future work
sections.text: In this paper, we have presented a novel approach to WSD in the biomedical field that achieves comparable performance with existing methods without taking into account the relational information from anonymity, making the approach easily transferable to other languages for which such ontologies may not exist, and to other areas. High accuracy in word embedding modification also opens up interesting prospects for improvement; better word representation leads to an improvement of our approach without modifying the approach itself. Furthermore, we would like to experiment with various composition functions for the composition of the definition and concept vectors.
